byline.contributor: David E. Sanger reported from Washington, and Nicole Perlroth from San Francisco.
byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and NICOLE PERLROTH

abstract: Suspicion that terrorists used sophisticated 'end-to-end' encryption apps to coordinate Paris attacks prompts intelligence officials to reopen debate over whether to compel companies to weaken encryption technologies; Belgian authorities note that Islamic State terrorists have been hiding communications using online gaming systems in which messages are not encrypted.
lead_paragraph: The attack has revived vitriolic arguments between American intelligence officials and Silicon Valley over whether the government should be given the keys to decode “end-to-end” encryption technology.

headline.main: Encrypted Messaging Apps Face New Scrutiny Over Possible Role in Paris Attacks
headline.print_headline: Encrypted Messaging Apps Face New Scrutiny Over Possible Role in Attacks

snippet: The attack has revived vitriolic arguments between American intelligence officials and Silicon Valley over whether the government should be given the keys to decode “end-to-end” encryption technology.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
